Lan Wangji has never visited Lotus Pier before. 

 

He’s only been to Yunmeng itself a couple of times, on night hunts with his xiongzhang. Growing up near the sea and the lakes of the Gusu district, he is more than accustomed to being surrounded by water, but Lotus Pier’s lakes are still a startling novelty. There are simply so many of them, woven into the piers and the city markets and even between the buildings. The air here is thick with a swampy humidity, nothing at all like the clear, crisp air of the mountains, even at this time of year. The sun bakes relentlessly through his robes as they walk, the summer heat entirely inescapable even in the reprieve of shade. 

 

Lotus Pier’s manor itself is also a small wonder. It’s strikingly different from the home Lan Wangji knows, warm wood tones and scatterings of lotus ponds weaving between the structures, the loud bustle and activity of disciples unfettered by rules. The scent of florals, lotus and camellia, is thick enough to taste, almost overly cloying. 

 

Even in less than a shichen of his visit, Lan Wangji begins to understand parts of Wei Wuxian he hadn’t put names to before. He watches his husband closely in the corner of his eye, the upbeat bounce in his step and the way he seems to relax into his whole being the further they wend their way through Lotus Pier. It’s an ease Lan Wangji has not seen in him since they married, even in Caiyi or traveling. It’s the ease of being home. Lan Wangji takes a moment to wonder if he, himself, feels such a way about the Cloud Recesses. Ease is not the word he would use to describe it.

 

They follow a stone-lined path toward a towering hall marked Sword Hall, Wei Wuxian leading the way with barely suppressed eagerness. Several young disciples are practicing forms in the courtyard, drenched in sweat. The moment they see Wei Wuxian, they drop their practice swords and descend on him with surprised shouts and joyful cries of “Da-shixiong, da-shixiong!” Wei Wuxian’s laughter is high and infectious; Wei Wuxian laughs with his whole chest, with every part of his body. It fills an entire space like the melt of sugar in a hot pan. Lan Wangji watches from a short distance away, feeling not quite unwelcome but certainly out of place. Warmth flares in him anyway, watching Wei Wuxian’s unbridled joy as he romps with the younger disciples, pinches their cheeks and pokes at their growing muscles and remarks on their improved skills. They flock around him in an adoring circle, their eyes wide and shining with admiration.

 

This is what Lan Wangji has taken from him. He reminds himself, again, that he’d hardly had a choice — that if it hadn’t been him, it would have been someone else. But he can’t help the guilt that prickles at him, seeing Wei Wuxian so openly adored, as he thinks of the treatment his husband has received within his own sect.

 

Finally, Wei Wuxian appears to remember his existence; he blinks over at Lan Wangji, then gives a dazzling smile with all his teeth and eagerly waves him over. Lan Wangji goes, maintaining his refined posture even as some of the younger disciples shy away from him, clearly intimidated.

 

“This is my husband, Lan Wangji,” Wei Wuxian tells the disciples. “I know you all have heard of Hanguang-jun’s legendary swordsmanship.”

 

The younger disciples nod and watch Lan Wangji silently, a little warily.

 

“Da-shixiong lives with Lan-qianbei now?” one of the younger-looking disciples asks doubtfully.

 

“Mhm,” Wei Wuxian says, crossing his arms over his chest. “I live in the mountains now, all the way out in Gusu by the ocean! There are lots of mountain monsters there to fight.”

 

“When will da-shixiong return to Lotus Pier?” the younger disciple asks, and Lan Wangji watches as Wei Wuxian’s face shutters, his smile cooling and his brightness dimming.

 

“A-Xian,” a woman’s voice cries out, ringing around the courtyard. Wei Wuxian’s head snaps toward the sound. “A-Xian, A-Xian!”

 

Jiang Yanli comes darting out of the hall, her pink and lavender silks swirling around her like butterfly wings. She would certainly be chastised for running in such a way in the Cloud Recesses, but Lan Wangji can’t find it in him to judge her as Wei Wuxian sprints to his sister, sinking into her embrace so hard that her feet leave the ground. They rock back and forth for a moment, both of their eyes squeezed shut. Jiang Yanli is crying, just a little. Lan Wangji doesn’t believe he has ever encountered Jiang Yanli in an instance when she hasn’t cried.

 

“A-Xian,” Jiang Yanli says when she finally pulls away with wet eyes, one of her hands cupping Wei Wuxian’s cheek. “You look so handsome! Clearly our friends in the GusuLan have been feeding you well.”

 

“Hardly!” Wei Wuxian complains, and pats her hand. “You should see the rabbit food they eat there, shijie. When are you going to come visit and make me a year’s worth of soup?”

 

Jiang Yanli laughs, and then her gaze slides past Wei Wuxian to refocus on Lan Wangji, who’s still loitering uncertainly by the disciples. Lan Wangji has been expecting to be met with tension, maybe hostility, and is surprised when Jiang Yanli’s eyes soften, a hand coming up to beckon to him.

 

“Lan er-gongzi, welcome to Lotus Pier,” she says as Lan Wangji nears the two of them. “It’s wonderful to see you here. Thank you for taking such good care of A-Xian.”

 

“Shijie,” Wei Wuxian protests. He folds his arms over his chest with a thump as he blows his bangs out of his face, his lower lip pouted. “It’s more like the other way around. Lan Zhan would be helpless on his own.”

 

Jiang Yanli glances at Lan Wangji again with sly amusement. “Is that true, Lan er-gongzi?”

 

“Very true,” Lan Wangji agrees, if only for the way Wei Wuxian lights up at his teasing. “I would be lost without him.”

 

It’s clearly the right response; Jiang Yanli laughs, a warm, bell-like sound with a similar cadence to Wei Wuxian’s, and she relaxes even further. Lan Wangji rarely has the correct response to conversational cues, and he’s surprised by the pleased warmth he feels about it. For the first time, he feels as though he might have a place here, temporary though it may be. 

 

“Come, come inside,” Jiang Yanli says, looping her arm through Wei Wuxian’s. “A-Cheng is waiting anxiously to see you, although he’s pretending that he’s not, so don’t tell him I said anything. The food just arrived.”

 

They curl close together as they walk, chattering happily while Lan Wangji follows behind in silence.

 

They’ve barely set foot in Sword Hall before a shadow falls in the entryway, a palpable cold front sweeping through the hall. Yu Ziyuan emerges with her hands folded tightly in her sleeves, focused on Wei Wuxian with the same venom Lan Wangji remembers from the wedding.

 

Wei Wuxian falters a step back, his arm slipping quickly from Jiang Yanli’s.

 

“A-niang,” Jiang Yanli murmurs, the warmth from her voice gone. She lowers her head and keeps it bowed, her eyes trained on the floor.

 

Yu Ziyuan ignores her, the scathing force of her gaze pinned on Wei Wuxian. “I thought I felt Lotus Pier’s doorstep darken. Who told you you were welcome back here?”

 

Lan Wangji can scarcely believe the hatred in her voice. Even the strictest of his elders have never spoken to him in such a way. 

 

“Jiang-shushu wrote and invited me, Yu-furen,” Wei Wuxian says respectfully. He also isn’t looking at her, watching the floor closely. “Lan Zhan has never visited Lotus Pier, so it seemed only right to bring him to meet you.”

 

Yu Ziyuan scoffs, turning to look critically at Lan Wangji. Lan Wangji lifts his chin and stares impassively back.

 

“Have you already grown sick of him, Lan er-gongzi?” Yu Ziyuan asks Lan Wangji. “I wouldn’t blame you if you cast him out after a month. If you kick him out of the Cloud Recesses, send him elsewhere. We don’t want him here.”

 

Wei Wuxian keeps his eyes lowered, the line of his shoulders tense. Lan Wangji breathes carefully around the anger he can feel pulsing in the center of him.

 

“On the contrary, Yu-furen,” he says. “Wei Ying’s company has been welcome.”

 

“Hmph!” Yu Ziyuan scoffs. “You’d be the first to say it. We only kept him around as long as we did because no one else was taking strays.”

 

“A-niang,” Jiang Yanli interjects in a pleading tone, her head still bowed. “Please. A-Xian is only here for a few days.”

 

“Who taught you to talk back?” Yu Ziyuan snaps, then directs her next words to Lan Wangji. “See the influence he has. Less than a shi back here and already my daughter is as uncouth as a servant.”

 

Lan Wangji has never heard Wei Wuxian so quiet. He can feel his fingernails digging into his own palms, clenched tight enough to sting.

 

It’s at that moment that Jiang Fengmian and Jiang Wanyin enter the hall. They pause in their tracks and their conversation, both visibly sizing up the tension in the room.

 

Then Jiang Wanyin squares his jaw and strides forward, past his mother, to envelop Wei Wuxian in a brisk hug.

 

“Welcome back, asshole,” he says, quiet enough for his parents not to hear. Wei Wuxian gives a small, strained laugh and pats his brother between the shoulder blades.

 

“A-Xian,” Jiang Fengmian says, also moving past Yu Ziyuan to greet them. “Lan er-gongzi, welcome. Have you not been offered tea? Come, come, there’s some waiting in the next room.”

 

Tea commences quickly and quietly from there, followed by a midday meal. It consists mostly of meat dishes reddened by spice, so Lan Wangji carefully picks his way around vegetable-based plates that won’t disagree with him. Jiang Fengmian cordially asks them about life in the Cloud Recesses, and Lan Wangji lets Wei Wuxian do the talking, although his responses are more subdued than usual, one-sentence replies with no elaboration. At one point, Jiang Yanli moves a pork bun onto Wei Wuxian’s plate, and Yu Ziyuan snaps at her for it. 

 

Wei Wuxian is silent throughout the rest of the meal, speaking only when asked direct questions.

 

“I see life in the Cloud Recesses has made A-Xian less inclined to chatter,” Jiang Fengmian says at one point with a forced smile, clearly also noticing the shift.

 

Yu Ziyuan makes a scornful sound in her throat. “All the better.”

 

Jiang Wanyin is openly glaring at Lan Wangji, the rest of his meal untouched.

 

“Forgive my lack of conversation, Jiang-shushu,” Wei Wuxian says, his tone polite. “It’s been a long few days of travel.”

 

Jiang Fengmian waves the apology away. “Of course. A-Xian and Lan er-gongzi must be tired. We won’t keep you, if you’d like to rest for the afternoon. Jinzhu and Yinzhu have prepared guest quarters for your stay.”

 

“Why not his old room?” Jiang Wanyin interjects.

 

“It didn’t seem big enough to accommodate two,” Jiang Fengmian replies. “Guest quarters offer more privacy as well.”

 

Jiang Wanyin makes a face at this, like he’d rather not consider it. Out of the corner of his eye, Lan Wangji watches Jiang Yanli gently squeeze Wei Wuxian’s knee, out of her mother’s eyeline. Just as surreptitiously, Wei Wuxian squeezes back. 

 

Yu Ziyuan speaks up then. “I was surprised to hear Lan er-gongzi had accepted my husband’s proposal. Wei Ying has little to offer the GusuLan sect, so the arrangement seemed improbable.”

 

Lan Wangji sets his chopsticks down with a quiet click. “The arrangement was advantageous to all involved parties. There was no reason to refuse.”

 

Yu Ziyuan sneers across the table, but it’s directed at Wei Wuxian. “Wei Ying is a servant’s son with a scoundrel’s track record. There was every reason to refuse.”

 

“I have come to value Wei Ying’s companionship,” Lan Wangji says before he can stop himself. “His blood is of no consequence to me.”

 

Wei Wuxian’s chopsticks pause, suspended in mid-air. He turns to stare at Lan Wangji with a blank expression. Almost uncertain, like he isn’t sure he’s not being tricked. Lan Wangji returns to his lotus soup as he picks his way around the pork, his ears overwarm. 

 

“What romantic notions you have about politics, Lan er-gongzi,” Yu Ziyuan says, her tone conversational but her derision clear.

 

“San niang,” Jiang Fengmian murmurs, and Yu Ziyuan scowls in his direction. Jiang Yanli and Jiang Wanyin are focused with extreme intensity on sipping their tea, looking like they’d rather shrink into the ground than sit here a moment longer.

 

“I didn’t expect an esteemed cultivator from a fellow sect of the gentry to hold such untoward views on servants,” Yu Ziyuan presses on. “I always thought the GusuLan to be far more traditional. In my MeishanYu sect, such an arrangement would never be allowed.”

 

For Lan Wangji’s many learned skills, repartée is not one of them. He remains quiet as he chews, the lotus between his teeth acrid to the taste. The answering silence from the others seated at the table is stilted as everyone pointedly avoids eye contact. 

 

“I suggested A-Cheng for the partnership, given A-Li was already betrothed to Jin Zixuan,” Yu Ziyuan continues into the awkward silence, more waspishly. “But my husband was insistent on giving this esteemed opportunity to Wei Ying.”

 

“A-niang,” Jiang Wanyin cuts in for the first time, sounding mortified.

 

“Quiet!” Yu Ziyuan snaps, and Jiang Wanyin nearly flinches.

 

“A-Cheng will focus on sect leadership, and then marriage,” Jiang Fengmian says firmly. It’s clear they’ve had this argument before, perhaps several times. 

 

What Lan Wangji would like to say is that the entire conversation is a moot point. If the offer had been Jiang Wanyin, he would have refused. He’s beginning to think that if the offer had been anyone else on earth besides Wei Ying, he would have refused.

 

The rest of the meal is relatively painless and civil, compared to that exchange, and then he and Wei Wuxian are being shown their rooms by Yu Ziyuan’s maids, brisk and unsmiling. Once they reach the guest chambers, the two women depart without a word. Wei Wuxian has lagged a few paces behind Lan Wangji, stopping at various distractions along the way.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian calls. Lan Wangji turns, and he finds Wei Wuxian watching him with a bemused expression. He quickens his steps so he’s at Lan Wangji’s side, tilting his head a little so his ponytail swings.

 

“Thank you for saying what you did in there,” Wei Wuxian says. “I know Yu-furen can be — a lot, on a first meeting. But you really didn’t have to go do all of that.”

 

All of what, Lan Wangji wonders. It had only been true. He had hardly said enough. 

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian repeats, still studying him with a thoughtful expression. “I have to say, you’re — you’re really not what I expected at all.”

 

Wei Wuxian had told him the same thing not long ago, in Caiyi Town. Lan Wangji wonders if he should take it as an insult that Wei Wuxian’s expectations of their marriage had apparently been so low.

 

“What did Wei Ying expect?” he says. It comes out a little testier than intended.

 

Wei Wuxian cocks his head, biting down on his lip and a smile in his eyes. “Well, for you to ignore me, mostly.”

 

“That can be arranged,” Lan Wangji says coolly.

 

Wei Wuxian throws his head back and laughs with genuine mirth, clutching his sides a little as he does. Lan Wangji shakes his head and starts to move toward the door again, but Wei Wuxian slides into his path, blocking him.

 

“As it turns out,” Wei Wuxian continues, his hands behind his back as he sways into Lan Wangji’s space, their chests almost touching. “Lan Zhan is an exceptionally good spouse in addition to being very handsome.”

 

The compliment is a shallow one, no doubt intended to tease, but Lan Wangji gets hot at it anyway, clenching his jaw against a blush.

 

“Ridiculous,” he mutters, and takes a large step back to put space between them.

 

“Yes,” Wei Wuxian agrees easily. “Lan Zhan, let’s go swimming.”

 

Lan Wangji just looks at him and doesn’t respond.

 

“There’s not much else to do here when it’s so hot out,” Wei Wuxian wheedles. “I want to show you the lakes. There are so many good ones, and it won’t be anyone but us, so you don’t have to worry about a bunch of strangers hanging around.”

 

Lan Wangji opens his mouth to refuse, and then he thinks, suddenly, of Wei Wuxian shrinking himself in Sword Hall, small and quiet and so like those first few days of their marriage.

 

“...fine,” he hears himself say. Wei Wuxian brightens, his eyes widening with surprised delight. He had expected Lan Wangji to say no. It’s odd, Lan Wangji thinks,  that anything he does is capable of truly surprising Wei Wuxian.

 

“Wait, really?” Wei Wuxian asks, bouncing onto his toes. He reaches out to squeeze both of Lan Wangji’s shoulders, and Lan Wangji blames the damnable heat for how warm he feels, sweat gathering on his lip and under the thick curtain of his hair. “This is gonna be great! Oh, wait, I know just the one. It’s not one of the more popular ones, so we won’t be bugged by Jiang disciples or by other swimmers. Come on, come on!” 

 

And with that, Lan Wangji finds himself being tugged out the door by the sleeve, down the steps and into the sunlight of the courtyard.

Wei Wuxian’s lake of choice isn’t far, but it is a little secluded, as promised. They travel through a few li’s worth of woods before the trees open up into a clearing. The lake here is hemmed in by rock cliffs, the waters a clear and startling shade of blue. The day is windless, so the surface of the lake barely ripples. It’s as though they’ve stumbled upon a sheet of glass, a pristine mirror to the sky. 

 

And Wei Wuxian is — disrobing. Already.

 

“Do you know how hard it is to wear black around here in the summer?” he complains, wriggling out of each layer so they crumple onto the ground. He almost trips taking off his shoes. His skin is flushed with heat, his limbs and hairline gleaming with sweat. Lan Wangji politely looks away as Wei Wuxian strips down to just his trousers.

 

“Lan Zhan, you’re not going to go swimming in all of your clothes, are you?” Wei Wuxian asks, sounding amused. “I mean, that would be very like you, but I don’t think it’s the best idea.”

 

“I,” Lan Wangji begins to reply, then makes the mistake of looking at Wei Wuxian while he does, and his tongue glues itself to the roof of his mouth.

 

His husband’s body is surprisingly toned, lean cords of muscle along his arms and chest, his abdomen. He has a swimmer’s build, narrow hips and his shoulders a little lanky. A dark trail of hair dips into the waistband of his trousers. Lan Wangji has seen glimpses of Wei Wuxian’s physique before — in Cold Spring, and in sharing quarters over the past few weeks — but never so directly, nor with a view so unimpeded. Fortunately, Wei Wuxian is in the middle of redoing his ponytail, his ribbon caught between his teeth as he works his fingers through his hair, so he doesn’t notice Lan Wangji’s sudden lapse, although he does turn to stare a little when Lan Wangji abruptly stops talking.

 

“I will,” Lan Wangji mutters, then looks off into the trees, trying to swallow down his embarrassment. 

 

“I won’t peek at you, if you don’t want me to,” Wei Wuxian says loyally, and Lan Wangji turns back to scowl at him in case he’s being teased. “I’m serious! I’m as straight-laced as an arrow, Lan Zhan. You won’t find any untoward thoughts here.”

 

Lan Wangji eyes him skeptically. Wei Wuxian tilts his head cutely back at him, smiling with charming innocence.

 

Menace, Lan Wangji thinks with great weariness, and he begins to slowly unpeel his own sweat-damp layers, folding each one as he goes and placing them atop a flat rock. 

 

True to his word, Wei Wuxian looks off toward the water for a few minutes, stretching his arms over his head. Then, being Wei Wuxian, he promptly forgets about it and turns toward Lan Wangji again once he’s undressed.

 

“Lan Zhan,” he says. “I want to show you —” Then he stops and stares at Lan Wangji. Lan Wangji stares back, prickling more with each second of scrutiny.

 

“What,” Lan Wangji snaps.

 

“Nothing!” Wei Wuxian says quickly, still staring. “You just have a nice body. Like, a really nice body. I wasn’t expecting — um, all of that, that’s all!”

 

Lan Wangji huffs and faces the water again, his ears hot.  

 

“Why do you get so mad when I compliment you?” Wei Wuxian asks. “Can’t married partners give each other compliments? Or is that against your 3,000 rules?”

 

Lan Wangji hesitates, then says, a little sullenly, “It is not.”

 

“Okay, good!” Wei Wuxian says. “I was just saying I want to show you something. Watch me.”

 

It’s become increasingly impossible not to, Lan Wangji thinks, observing Wei Wuxian covertly from the corner of his eye. Wei Wuxian sets Suibian on the ground and fits his bare feet to the hilt, and then he’s rising off the ground, spitting up sand as he goes. Wei Wuxian rides a sword with expert athleticism and a cocky ease, throwing his weight smoothly so he bobs and weaves. Now is no different even as he crouches a little for balance, speeding out toward the lake. He ascends higher and higher, and then, with his feet still attached to Suibian, he flips, three rotations, directly into the water.

 

On instinct, Lan Wangji takes a step forward when Wei Wuxian vanishes into the blue, leaving only a bubbling wake behind. Several long seconds pass, and then Wei Wuxian bursts up with a splash, his peals of laughter bouncing off the water and shimmering against the cliff faces.

 

“Wasn’t that great!” Wei Wuxian calls over to him. He starts to paddle toward the shore, Suibian clutched in one hand. “Lan Zhan, come in already, the water’s so nice!”

 

Lan Wangji sighs, then steps into the water so he’s ankle-deep. It is a nice temperature, nowhere near the degree of Cold Spring’s, but refreshing for a day as hot as this one. Wei Wuxian sends Suibian to the shore and treads water as he waits, spectating with clear humor as Lan Wangji picks his way along the lake bottom, careful to avoid rocks and branches. Finally, he catches up to Wei Wuxian, his feet leaving the lakebed to tread next to him. 

 

Lan Wangji only ever uses Cold Spring for cultivation, meditation, or healing purposes; he has never swam there for fun, or even considered it. He hasn’t swam for the simple sake of swimming since he was a child. It feels strange to bob in the lake without a real purpose, with only the water bearing his weight aloft.

 

“Lan Zhan, wasn’t that trick great,” Wei Wuxian says again, clearly fishing for compliments. When Lan Wangji nods, he adds, “Jiang Cheng and I used to practice it all the time, when we could sneak away from training. We used to host these competitions with the other disciples to see who could pull off the best tricks.”

 

“What did you win?” Lan Wangji asks, drifting closer to Wei Wuxian.

 

“Bragging rights, mostly,” Wei Wuxian replies. He lets himself float on his back, his limbs starfished outward. “Sometimes we’d pool our money together and get a betting ring going, and the winner would take all. Jiang Cheng was so pissed whenever I beat him, which was all of the time. I’d blow all my money on food and liquor like, right away, and Jiang Cheng would yell at me about saving it, the little shit.”

 

Lan Wangji hums for lack of better response, just to show he’s listening.

 

“He’s always kind of thought about things like a sect leader,” Wei Wuxian says to the sky. “It was sort of pounded into him when we were kids, you know?”

 

Lan Wangji hums again.

 

“Lan Zhan, am I boring you?” Wei Wuxian asks, splashing a little as he rights himself in the water. 

 

“Wei Ying could never be boring,” Lan Wangji says dryly, and he means every word.

 

Wei Wuxian cracks a toothy grin, then moves toward him with a smooth stroke of his arms. Just as steadily, Lan Wangji retreats from him. It pushes them both backwards so that Lan Wangji’s feet find the lake bottom again, cool mud squishing between his toes. Lan Wangji remains patiently still as Wei Wuxian circles him around and around in the water like a shark. Once Wei Wuxian is behind him, Lan Wangji feels hands press down onto his bare shoulders as Wei Wuxian throws his weight, doing all in his power to shove Lan Wangji underwater.

 

“Wei Ying!” Lan Wangji protests, swatting him away and blinking spray out of his eyes. Wei Wuxian back-paddles with his feet and cackles, the sun-gold lines of his face alight with mirth. Watching him, feeling his heart skip as he does, Lan Wangji comes to the rather abrupt realization that he would do any manner of ridiculous and improper things to keep Wei Wuxian looking like that.

 

But whatever Wei Wuxian sees in Lan Wangji’s face in return causes some kind of shuttering. He blinks and straightens in the water, becoming more serious as he says, “Sorry, Lan Zhan.”

 

Not for the first time, Lan Wangji wonders what it was that was said to Wei Ying — when, and by whom — to instill fear that had never existed there before their marriage. He has his guesses, and it makes his knuckles curl at his sides.

 

It’s this line of thought that impels Lan Wangji to reach out, plant one hand on the top of Wei Wuxian’s head, and forcefully dunk him.

 

Wei Wuxian comes up spluttering and hacking in shock. He blinks at Lan Wangji in pure disbelief, his mouth ajar as water drips down his face.

 

“Did you really just!” Wei Wuxian says.

 

“Mm,” says Lan Wangji.

 

“You…” Wei Wuxian’s face hardens with determination, a challenging smirk sharp against his cheek. It’s an expression that signals danger, from personal experience on the receiving end of it. Before Lan Wangji can blink, Wei Wuxian flies at him, a wet smack and a grunt as their bodies collide, skin and muscle, Wei Wuxian’s wiry arms wrapping around his waist to shove him back into the water. It’s the surprise of it, more than Wei Wuxian’s strength, that imbalances Lan Wangji; he stumbles, the soles of his feet sliding in the slimy algae on the lakebed, and Wei Wuxian very nearly takes him down. Lan Wangji is halfway distracted by the feeling of Wei Wuxian tangled up around him, laughing and laughing, the sound and closeness of him warmer than daylight. Lan Wangji had never roughhoused as a boy; had never even imagined doing such a thing, with his peers or with his xiongzhang. Infighting had been prohibited, and tactile play discouraged. He isn’t sure what to do with his arms or his hands. He stands in the water as immovable as a boulder, awkward and stiff and burning as Wei Wuxian keeps trying to shove him off-balance.

 

“Aiyo, Lan Zhan, give me some face, will you?” Wei Wuxian whines, scrabbling ineffectively at Lan Wangji’s shoulders. “Let me dunk you just once.”

 

Instead, on some instinct, Lan Wangji gathers Wei Wuxian’s wrists easily in one hand and holds them above his head. Wei Wuxian’s physical strength is not to be underestimated, but Lan Wangji is stronger, taller by a cun and wider by a few more. A thrill courses through him at how easy it is to overpower Wei Wuxian, even as his muscles ripple with effort, as he whines and thrashes and puts up a good fight to free himself from Lan Wangji’s grip; almost a good enough fight. Lan Wangji has heard other men say that maidens’ fragility, their vulnerability, is the quality that attracts them, but it’s Wei Wuxian’s physical strength that sparks something carnal in him, some hot pulse in the core of him that’s impossible to temper. That threat of being outmatched and winning anyway; of Wei Wuxian giving as good as he’s got, shoving Lan Wangji around before he inevitably loses, before Lan Wangji pins him and breaks him open.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian protests harder as he struggles. He juts his lower lip out in a pout, pink and glistening with lakewater. Lan Wangji observes the thought, as though from a clinical distance, that he wants to bite it. “So beastly, so brutish! Is this how cruelly you treat all of your husbands?”

 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says, following the line of inquiry with an interested hunger. He tightens his grip around Wei Wuxian’s wrists, tight enough that Wei Wuxian squeaks ah in either pain or breathy surprise. “It is.”

 

Wei Wuxian stops struggling for a moment, his eyes slightly round in his face. His skin is pinker now, beyond the sun-flush already reddening his cheeks.

 

Then, with his wrists still pinned, he slinks under the surface of the water, blowing bubbles as he goes. Lan Wangji hardly has time to question it before Wei Wuxian surfaces, spitting a stream directly into Lan Wangji’s face. It disarms Lan Wangji enough that he flinches back, his grip on Wei Wuxian’s wrists loosening as he blinks through water and — and Wei Wuxian’s spit, the thought of which should not affect him either way — and his slip gives Wei Wuxian the opening he needs. Wei Wuxian crows in victory and pounces, tackling Lan Wangji into the water and taking them both down with a thundering splash. 

 

Lan Wangji crashes under, the sounds of the surface hollowing out into quiet, Wei Wuxian’s limbs tangled up with his, Wei Wuxian’s hair in his mouth, Wei Wuxian’s thigh caught between both of his. There are too many points of contact to focus on; it’s the most they’ve touched, more than their wedding night, more than Lan Wangji has ever been touched at once, and he thinks, for a free, fleeting, floating moment, that he could stay here until his breath bottoms out, grip on tight to Wei Wuxian until they’re one strange and conjoined form, away from the clamoring expectations above the surface — except then Wei Wuxian is pulling him up, hauling him toward the sun. Air splits over his head, the return of sound bursting around him. Lan Wangji chokes trying to catch his breath.

 

“Ah,” Wei Wuxian says with fond concern, but he’s laughing, laughing too much for genuine worry. He’s scooping Lan Wangji’s dripping hair out of his face. “Did I almost drown my husband? Please don’t report me for attempted mariticide, Lan Zhan, my reputation really can’t withstand it.”

 

He says that more and more often now, breezy and thoughtless and half-facetious, my husband, like it’s always been this way, like he’d chosen it this way, like they’re really…

 

Wei Wuxian teases, Lan Wangji reminds himself with a steeling breath. Oxygen scrapes the bottom of his lungs. Wei Wuxian teases everyone.

 

“We should go,” Lan Wangji says. On instinct, he reaches up to adjust his headband before he remembers he’d left it on the shore. “Your family will be expecting us.”

 

Wei Wuxian groans and sulks at him. “So easily conceding defeat, Lan Zhan? I never took you for a quitter!”

 

Lan Wangji ignores him and begins wading back toward the shore. He hears Wei Wuxian splash around behind him before he follows with sighing and grumbled protests. Then he feels hands on his shoulders again, and the next thing he knows, Wei Wuxian is climbing him like a tree, surprisingly nimble, each of his limbs wrapping tight around Lan Wangji’s torso and clinging.

 

Lan Wangji tries to throw him off, but Wei Wuxian only grips on tighter, cackling in his ear. Wei Wuxian’s trousers are sheer and wet enough that Lan Wangji can feel something very distinct pressed against his back. Obviously Wei Wuxian isn’t hard, but the shape of what he can feel is enough to make Lan Wangji’s throat dry as a bone, his cheeks smarting with heat.

 

Wei Wuxian hums and rests his chin on Lan Wangji’s wet shoulder, still clinging onto him. “Do you forfeit yet, Lan Zhan?”

 

“If I do, will you get off of me?” Lan Wangji replies through gritted teeth.

 

“I think my husband should have to carry me like this everywhere,” Wei Wuxian says primly, then gives a kick to his side like he’s leading a horse. “My feet should never touch the ground again!”

 

Then he bites Lan Wangji’s ear.

 

Lan Wangji stiffens, goosebumps rippling all the way up his back. At the same time, Wei Wuxian loosens his grip like he’s been unbalanced, scrambling back into the water with a racketing splash.

 

“Sorry, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says when he resurfaces, his eyes a little wide. “I don’t know why I — um! I got. Carried away.”

 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says stiffly, and wades his way back toward the shore. His earlobe is still burning where Wei Wuxian’s teeth had sunk in. His entire body feels hot, in spite of the cool water.

 

Neither of them speak as they stumble back into their robes and their shoes. The whole scenario feels ridiculous now, in hindsight; that Wei Wuxian had somehow tricked him out of his clothes and into the water like some huli jing. Something for him to gloat about, perhaps. Heedless, as always, to leaving others in turmoil. 

 

“Hey, you’re not mad, are you?” Wei Wuxian asks into Lan Wangji’s silence. “I was just messing around.”

 

“Messing around,” Lan Wangji echoes, his voice thin.

 

“Yeah, messing around,” Wei Wuxian says. “The way I’d do with Jiang Cheng or Nie Huaisang.”

 

The idea of Wei Wuxian casually straddling Nie Huaisang’s back makes Lan Wangji even angrier. He gives a snap of his sleeve and strides off toward the woods, with little to no direction as to where he’s going but desperate to make a dignified exit regardless.

 

“Lan Zhan, the manor is that way!” Wei Wuxian calls, unable to keep the laugh entirely from his voice, and Lan Wangji’s temper sours further. He turns to glare at Wei Wuxian, who falters and quits smiling when he sees the expression.

 

“Ah, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says, sounding a little breathless. “You haven’t looked at me this way since...did I really offend you so much?”

 

“Let’s go,” Lan Wangji says, unwilling to talk about it further. The more Wei Wuxian probes, the more it will become glaringly obvious that Lan Wangji’s anger has no root in anything that makes sense to him.

 

“Okay,” Wei Wuxian says agreeably, and catches up to Lan Wangji.

 

They pass the first couple of li in silence, twigs and leaves crackling under their wet shoes.

 

Then:

 

“Hey, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says, and scratches his head. “I have a question.”

 

Bodes ill. Lan Wangji inclines his head to grant the request.

 

“If you could have had it any other way,” Wei Wuxian says. “What would your ideal wife be like?”

 

The question is unexpected enough that it almost shakes Lan Wangji out of his sulk. Almost.

 

“Never pictured it before,” Lan Wangji says, wishing to be away from this topic. “I never thought overmuch about marriage.”

 

“Hmmm,” Wei Wuxian says, then maintains a pensive silence as they keep walking.

 

A smatter of birdsong, wheeling and plaintive. A chorus of frogs and cicadas, burring loud as sunset approaches.

 

“Well, if you tell me, whatever it is,” Wei Wuxian says. He is unmistakably earnest. “I’ll try my best to be more like that.”

 

Lan Wangji frowns his displeasure, his former mood forgotten. “No need.”

 

“Of course it is!” Wei Wuxian says. “I don’t want you to be sad your whole life because of me. That would be so selfish! I know I’m exactly not what you, ah, pictured, and —”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji interrupts. “There is no need.”

 

“Fine, fine.” Wei Wuxian audibly pouts. “I was just trying to be nice.”

 

“I never wanted a wife,” Lan Wangji says. He immediately wishes he could take it back. It feels too close to an admission he does not want to make.

 

“Oh?” says Wei Wuxian.

 

“No,” Lan Wangji says, then swallows. 

 

Wei Wuxian falls quiet again for a long time, his silhouette lined dark in the falling light. He appears to be thinking hard on something. Lan Wangji waits with breath bated for what he’ll say.

 

“I’m sorry you had to get married,” Wei Wuxian says slowly. “Even though you didn’t want to.”

 

That is not what Lan Wangji had said. He had said he hadn’t wanted a wife. He opens his mouth to correct Wei Wuxian, then shuts it again. Perhaps safer, this way.

 

“But I promise,” Wei Wuxian says. He sticks up three fingers, the whites of his eyes visible even in the growing dark. “I’ll do my best to make it not all bad, okay?”

 

Lan Wangji breathes out. The evening’s first stars wink through the dark slivers in the trees. 

 

“Okay,” he says, and they walk until the moon rises.

 

 

 

 

 

 

◈ ◈ ◈

 

Their stay in Lotus Pier passes surprisingly quickly. 

 

Wei Wuxian devotes most of it to romping with his siblings, so Lan Wangji spends much of his time there alone. He doesn’t mind. Lotus Pier has an extensive library — nowhere near the breadth of the Cloud Recesses’, but with new and different materials — and beautiful sights, and the paths around the water channels are easily walkable. He has never minded solitude, and he can’t begrudge Wei Ying at all for wanting to spend time with his family, especially when he returns to Lan Wangji in the evenings with a wine-flush in his cheeks, his eyes bright with happiness. 

 

Later into their trip, Wei Wuxian returns to their shared quarters a little drunker than the previous nights, and he immediately makes a bid for Lan Wangji’s attention — which, of course, he already has. 

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian tells the ceiling as he sprawls on the floor, his eyes closed. A faint smile curves his lips. “Did you know I always really wanted to bring you here?”

 

Lan Wangji did not know. It makes something in him go soft and warm. “No.”

 

“Yeah,” Wei Wuxian sighs, then he yawns. “That first summer, after we studied together. I kept hoping you would come visit me. And then I could show you around, just like this. I had all sorts of terrible things planned for you, just so I could laugh at you a little, but not — not in a mean way, I just. Missed laughing at you, when you weren’t here.”

 

“Hm,” Lan Wangji says, soft enough to prompt Wei Wuxian to continue.

 

“Now it’s all perfect,” Wei Wuxian mumbles. “You’re here and Jiang Cheng’s here and shijie’s here.”

 

They have three days left in Lotus Pier before they’re expected home. Lan Wangji is sure Wei Wuxian is aware. It’s perhaps, even, the reason for his inebriation.

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says quietly, but Wei Wuxian is already asleep, his face still flushed and his head tilted to the side. He’s childlike when he sleeps, even more so than when he’s awake, a natural pout of his mouth and his cheeks a little puffed. 

 

Lan Wangji is able to lift him easily to move him to the bed. He stares at Wei Wuxian's sleeping form for another moment, unimpeded now to drink his fill without being caught, before guilt gnaws at him with small teeth. It is allowed, he reminds himself. They are married. Is there something morally wrong with looking at one’s husband? With caring for him?

 

Wei Wuxian had toed off his shoes at the door, but Lan Wangji removes what else he can, moving with care so as not to wake him. His belt, which makes his face heat at the implications; he does not dare venture any further than that. His socks. His hair ribbon, which he places next to the bed. Lan Wangji has never been one to initiate touch with others. He’d never had any desire to, avoiding physical contact even from family members. 

 

With Wei Ying, his hands are treacherous. They betray him to himself. They move of their own will, always unconsciously roaming or reaching out. He wants Wei Ying’s skin and his warmth and the curve of his cheek against his mouth. He wants everything, and it is a cataclysm.

 

Lan Wangji turns onto his back and watches the silver latticework of moonlight across the ceiling. He keeps his hands tucked close to his chest, and he burns.

Their visit is not all idyllic, of course. 

 

Yu Ziyuan’s presence lurks like a thunderhead, an ever-present bitter charge in the backdrop. Meals with the Jiangs are mostly silent, or strained with tension. Lan Wangji notices that Wei Wuxian stays out of her way, taking care to avoid being underfoot, but Yu Ziyuan seems to seek him out with uncanny precision, and it is always with a prepared diatribe or a sneer on her lips.

 

On the last afternoon before their departure, Lan Wangji finds himself at the entrance of Sword Hall again, searching for Wei Ying, and realizes quickly that he’s intruded on the tail-end of an argument. Perhaps not so much an argument as Yu Ziyuan berating Wei Wuxian — something about his conduct around the younger disciples — while Wei Wuxian stands there with his head lowered, a defiant jut of his jaw, his hands clenched by his sides. He says something in reply to Yu Ziyuan that Lan Wangji cannot hear. 

 

The moment Lan Wangji enters the hall is when Yu Ziyuan slaps Wei Wuxian so hard across the face that a crack rings around the room. It is not a light swat. Yu Ziyuan puts her whole arm into the blow, with such a force that Wei Wuxian stumbles, his neck wrenched to the side and his hair whipped into his face.

 

Lan Wangji feels his entire body flash hot, then cold, a crystallizing ice that spreads and burns. The reaction is instinctive, visceral. Before he knows what he’s doing, he’s taking a step forward to announce his presence, his hand on the hilt of his sword.

 

If she’s surprised to see him, Yu Ziyuan doesn’t show it. She turns to survey Lan Wangji with evident disinterest. Her eyes drop to Bichen, then travel back up to Lan Wangji’s face with a small, venomous smirk.

 

“What is it, Lan er-gongzi?” she asks. “Have you never seen a servant disciplined?”

 

Wei Wuxian walks quickly toward Lan Wangji, his head down and his eyes averted. He doesn’t pause in his steps even as he grabs Lan Wangji’s arm to pull him back toward the hall’s entrance. Lan Wangji doesn’t budge. His hand hasn’t moved from his sword. Neither he nor Yu Ziyuan have backed down from glaring at each other, a silent standoff that drops the room’s temperature steadily by degrees.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says in a low voice, still facing the exit. “It’s not worth it. Let’s just go.”

 

Zidian flickers to life on Yu Ziyuan’s hand, a violet crackle of electricity. At the sound, Wei Wuxian yanks his arm harder.

 

“Lan Wangji,” he snaps, with a much harder edge than before.

 

Yu Ziyuan would never dream of injuring Lan Wangji, for multiple reasons — his status, his sect background, their newly minted alliance. All three of them know this. It doesn’t stop Yu Ziyuan from flexing her hand so that the snake on her wrist uncoils, a pointed reminder of the power she wields. 

 

It is only Wei Wuxian’s palpable tension that prompts Lan Wangji to turn and follow him out to the pavilion. Wei Wuxian doesn’t stop even once they pass their quarters, plowing forward with a single-minded focus until Lan Wangji tugs on his arm to stop him. 

 

Wei Wuxian does, then turns to eye him warily. His cheek has already puffed up from the strike, the skin reddened.

 

“Does it…” Lan Wangji’s hand drifts up automatically to touch, and then he remembers himself and returns it to his side. “Are you alright?”

 

“I’m fine,” Wei Wuxian answers at once. “Really, I’m fine, Lan Zhan, I’m not just saying that.” 

 

“Would it be better if we...” Lan Wangji hesitates. Go home suddenly seems like the wrong thing to say. “...left a day early?”

 

“No!” Wei Wuxian says, with something like panic. “No, we don’t need to do that. I’m really fine.” He raises one hand to massage his jaw, then turns to the side to casually spit out a mouthful of blood. “Nicked my cheek, though.” Then he beams at Lan Wangji. His teeth are red.

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says quietly.

 

“Don’t,” Wei Wuxian says, his smile fading at the corners. “Really, don’t. It barely even hurt. It’s much better that it’s me than Jiang Cheng or shijie.”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says again.

 

“Lan Zhan, I mean it,” Wei Wuxian says, beginning to bristle. He is so rarely unsmiling. It’s interesting to know, with each passing day of their marriage, what pushes Wei Wuxian to an edge, what shakes him out of façade and closer to genuine reaction.

 

“I know,” Lan Wangji says. “Will you show me the market?”

 

Wei Wuxian freezes in the middle of whatever he’s charging up to say. For a few seconds, he blinks at Lan Wangji, looking flabbergasted. “What?”

 

“The market,” Lan Wangji repeats. “I would like to see it.”

 

Wei Wuxian hasn’t fully untensed, but curiosity seems to win out over his skepticism. “Really?”

 

Lan Wangji nods.

 

“Oh. Well. Okay.” Each word is punctuated with a blink. Wei Wuxian still looks a little wary, like he suspects this may be a pity outing. Lan Wangji has found, with increasing clarity, that Wei Ying reacts to pity in the visceral way that most would to insult or injury. By contrast, insult and injury find him with a smile on his face.

 

Every new thing he learns complicates his initial impression of Wei Ying, from those first few months. Complicates it, and…

 

“Well, sure, if you really want to,” Wei Wuxian is saying. “Let’s go now if we’re going though, yeah?”

 

They do.

 

The distance to the main market stretch isn’t far, but Wei Wuxian’s steps seem to grow lighter the further they wander from the manor. He’s practically skipping by the time they reach the first set of stalls along the water. 

 

Most of the vendors know Wei Wuxian by name, calling out in excited recognition when they see him. He doesn’t ignore a single one; each time his name is called, he drags Lan Wangji over to meet whoever it is, to make chirping small talk or to toss flirtations their way like flower petals. Neither age nor gender seem to be discriminating factors for who catches and receives Wei Wuxian’s attention. Lan Wangji has grown deeply sullen about it by the fifth blushing shopkeeper, by which point Wei Wuxian’s arms are overflowing with fresh jujubes and loquats and bags of lotus seeds and water chestnuts.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says with a tiny grin, watching him as they walk. “What’s that face for?”

 

“Don’t flirt casually,” Lan Wangji says before he can stop himself. He cannot quite help how petulant he sounds. “If you do not mean it.”

 

Wei Wuxian’s smile splits even wider, the kind where he crinkles around the eyes. He pauses for a moment to gently deposit his stash of food into the open hands of two street beggars, neither of whom can be older than ten. They tear off the moment they have the food, their bare feet slapping in the packed dirt. 

 

“You want me to flirt with just you, is that it?” Wei Wuxian asks, turning back to Lan Wangji with a gleam in his eye.

 

Lan Wangji opens his mouth to respond, but he finds he can’t say a word to defend himself. He looks away, burning.

 

Wei Wuxian laughs at him, which Lan Wangji thinks is probably, in this case, deserved. “Okay, I get it, I understand. I’ll only flirt with my husband from now on, how does that sound?”

 

Good, the buried, possessive part of Lan Wangji thinks before he can stop himself.

 

“It is only proper, when one is married,” he says instead. It sounds like a good enough excuse.

 

Wei Wuxian nods with mock solemnity. “Indeed, indeed. The matter of extramarital flirting is not to be taken lightly.”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, irritable at being teased.

 

Wei Wuxian wraps both arms around one of Lan Wangji’s and sways into his space, his eyes glinting with mischief.

 

“Foolish me,” Wei Wuxian says with a theatrical sigh, “to flirt with anyone else when Lan Zhan is the most beautiful person in all of Lotus Pier.”

 

Lan Wangji really cannot abide by teasing like this at all. He tries to pull his arm from Wei Wuxian’s grasp again, keeping his gaze averted as his ears heat.

 

“You asked for flirting!” Wei Wuxian reminds him, clinging on tighter. “Now take responsibility!”

 

“I did not ask,” Lan Wangji protests.

 

“You did! Oh, let’s stop here, this one’s my favorite.”

 

With that, he drags Lan Wangji into a restaurant teeming with people. Through charm and some finagling, Wei Wuxian is able to procure them a table despite the packed quarters, where he promptly orders a smattering of smaller plates. Lan Wangji hears him rattle off mapo doufu, niushe bing, and shangxian liangfen, and one other he doesn’t hear above the din of patrons talking. 

 

“Ah, shit, I forgot to order something without spice,” Wei Wuxian says apologetically once the server leaves. “Although I think your options in that area are quite limited.”

 

“No need,” Lan Wangji says, folding his hands in his lap. He’s not hungry.

 

It doesn’t take long for the food to arrive, sizzling and smoking and, for the most part, very red. Wei Wuxian starts to pick various food off of the plates, sampling each one with loud sounds of enjoyment.

 

“Don’t get me wrong, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says through watering eyes. “The GusuLan are very, um, nice to provide meals for me. It’s just that I missed real food so much! Like, this one, the tofu, it has —”

 

“I will try it,” Lan Wangji says.

 

Wei Wuxian glances up to appraise him with raised eyebrows. “Lan Zhan, are you sure? It’s, ah. It might be different from what you’ve had. They make it pretty hot around here.”

 

“I will try it,” Lan Wangji repeats, more stubbornly. Wei Wuxian has molded himself to fit a Lan lifestyle, a Lan diet, Lan clothes and traditions. He wants to love Lotus Pier the way Wei Wuxian does, its food and its people and every moving, breathing piece of this place that has made Wei Ying who he is.

 

Wei Wuxian blinks at him, his gaze gentling and his mouth curving up into a tiny smile before a quicker, broader grin overshadows it. “Okay! This one’s one of my favorites.”

 

He picks a cube of tofu up with his chopsticks, drenched in red sauce, and holds his sleeve as he reaches across the table. The intimacy of hand-feeding certainly does not escape Lan Wangji as he leans forward, his lips burning the moment they make contact with Wei Wuxian’s chopsticks. The spice’s heat rises to his face quickly as he does his best to chew. As he swallows, a path of fire traces down his chest. 

 

Wei Wuxian watches him eagerly the whole time, perched cross-legged and leaning forward across the table. Lan Wangji can feel the reflexive tears wetting his lashes, his sinuses activating as he gives a quiet, miserable cough.

 

“Lan Zhan ah, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says as he circles the table and plops down next to him. “Lan Zhan, you’re so cute! There was hardly any spice on that piece!”

 

“Hm,” Lan Wangji rasps, coughing again and tearing up harder. 

 

Wei Wuxian hums and lifts his sleeve to wipe the tears away, dabbing at Lan Wangji’s hot cheeks. “This dutiful husband won’t force you to try any more, okay? Aiyo, your poor red face, look at you, tch.”

 

Lan Wangji goes still at Wei Wuxian’s fussing, the pain of the spice entirely forgotten. Wei Wuxian freezes at the same time, his hands stilling and his wide eyes locked with Lan Wangji’s. There’s another moment where they stare at each other, and then Wei Wuxian is retreating, hitting his knee on the table as he goes, as he laughs and dodges and hand-waves.

 

“So there you have it, you can say now that you’ve tried the best of Yunmeng’s cuisine and survived!”

 

Now that Lan Wangji has recovered a little, he nods with determination toward the bowl of jelly noodles. “That one.”

 

“No!” Wei Wuxian says, paling. “Lan Zhan, I think you would really die if you tried shangxin liangfen. I, aha, appreciate your fortitude, but I really enjoy not being a widow.”

 

Wei Wuxian looks genuinely fearful for his life, so Lan Wangji nods and concedes. And, after a few minutes — when Wei Wuxian takes a few bites of the dish and immediately coughs and flushes red — Lan Wangji determines the decision was probably for the better.

 

By the time they leave the restaurant, the sun has begun to set, casting a low golden light like a fishing net over the market. The channels of water surrounding them fade from blue to bronze to rose and lavender as they wend their way down the main road, leisurely in pace as Wei Wuxian bounces from stall to stall.

 

“Handsome gege!” a couple of young women exclaim to Wei Wuxian when the two of them walk past. Their arms are full to bursting with colorful blooms. “Gongzi, won’t you take some flowers?”

 

Wei Wuxian laughs as the women shower him with peonies and chrysanthemums, loose petals catching in his hair and robes.

 

“I’m flattered, guniangmen,” he calls back, then gestures toward Lan Wangji. “But isn’t this one much more handsome?”

 

“Very handsome!” the women agree, audibly sighing as they clutch their flowers closer to their chest.

 

Wei Wuxian pauses in his steps to turn toward Lan Wangji, and Lan Wangji follows suit. With a faint smile, Wei Wuxian reaches up to tuck a peony behind Lan Wangji’s ear, adjusting a few strands of hair as he does. Lan Wangji’s heart pounds.

Something already in motion, taking distinct shape before he knew a name for it. The roots of it he can trace to before their marriage, now that he knows what to look for, what to feel for.

Less industrious, more...joyful.

Wei Wuxian glances at him with a small, sad smile. “I know we have to leave tomorrow. It was great I got to come here at all. But it’s hard not to be homesick for a place like this, you know?”

 

“Of course,” Lan Wangji says. He takes another step so their shoulders are level with each other’s. “Wei Ying, we can visit as much as you like. You are not a prisoner of the GusuLan.”

 

Wei Wuxian sighs and looks away toward the water again. “It’s sweet of you to say so.”

 

The way he says it makes Lan Wangji think he hasn’t been believed.

Wei Wuxian is quiet the next day after they depart from Lotus Pier. 

 

He puts on a bright face through the farewells, wheeling out jokes and assuaging words. Jiang Yanli cries again when they say goodbye, while Jiang Wanyin holds himself rigid throughout it, his nostrils flared and his mouth tight. Yu Ziyuan is not in attendance to see him off, but Jiang Fengmian sends them with gifts that they can stow in their qiankun pouches, money packets and dry snacks for their journey.

 

However, Wei Wuxian is unsmiling when they mount their swords, and in the shichen of flying after. There is none of the carefree joy from their initial flight here. Wei Wuxian remains withdrawn and somber, hardly looking at Lan Wangji.

 

They land only once they run into a storm near sundown, a wind-whipped rain needling them even through their clothes. Lan Wangji leads them down to the nearest town where they can find refuge for the evening. Wei Wuxian follows him without protest, answering in one-word replies when Lan Wangji asks what he’d like for supper.

 

The inn they find, one of the only in the village, is nearly at capacity, but the innkeeper takes one look at Lan Wangji’s clothing and his jade pendant and he scrambles to find room for them. All around them, men and women are drinking and chattering, a din of sound above the rain.

 

Wei Wuxian only perks up when two men nearby mention the sighting of two yaoguai in the next town over. After a moment of eavesdropping on the various gory details of the most recent attack, Wei Wuxian turns to Lan Wangji with a strange intensity.

 

“A night-hunt just fell right into our laps, Lan Zhan!” he says. “We should set out for Pailou tomorrow morning.”

 

Lan Wangji hesitates. He doesn’t want to quash Wei Wuxian’s newfound excitement, so he says, “Let’s speak of it later.”

 

Wei Wuxian procures a pot of liquor, and then they follow the innkeeper to a room out in the courtyard, one of the larger chambers with direct access to the outdoors.

 

“I’ve taken down more yaoguai than I can count on two hands,” Wei Wuxian is saying as soon as they’re inside. He wrings rainwater out of his hair, out of his sleeves. “These two should be no problem. And it sounds like they’re really causing the locals some problems, so —”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji interrupts quietly.

 

Wei Wuxian freezes at his tone, his hands going still. “What?”

 

“We cannot,” Lan Wangji says. He doesn’t want to disappoint Wei Wuxian, especially not right now, and the feeling of knowing he’s about to is leaden.

 

Wei Wuxian frowns, his demeanor cooling. “Why not?”

 

“There is a sect conference in Gusu, in two days’ time,” Lan Wangji says. It sounds trite when he says it, so he adds, “An important one,” which makes it sound more trite.

 

Wei Wuxian stares at him as though he’s suddenly sprouted a tail. “A conf—...there are people here who are getting hurt. Who are dying. It’s our responsibility as cultivators to do something about it.”

 

“My sect will send another cultivator to handle it,” Lan Wangji answers. He hates the way it sounds, coming out of his mouth.

 

“And waste days’ worth of time?” Wei Wuxian retorts, his fists clenching at his sides. “Why should we risk people’s lives when we’re right here and can take care of it?”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says, then takes a breath. “I have certain responsibilities.”

 

“So you go, and I’ll stay here and deal with this.”

 

Lan Wangji swallows. He doesn’t look Wei Wuxian in the eye, his gaze settling instead somewhere on his chest. “Wei Ying’s attendance, as my new spouse and as a representative for the YunmengJiang, will be expected.”

 

“You mean as your servant,” Wei Wuxian whips back. The words cut, stinging and barbed.

 

“No,” Lan Wangji says carefully. “As my husband.”

 

“Why exactly am I expected to be there?” Wei Wuxian’s whole body has gone tight with tension. “You think any of those gentry cultivators care about what I have to say? About anything?”

 

“For appearances’ sake,” Lan Wangji tries to explain, and he knows he’s said the wrong thing because Wei Wuxian falters a step back toward the door and laughs. It is not a kind laugh. It’s perhaps the first time Lan Wangji has heard Wei Wuxian laugh with no joy behind it.

 

“Right, appearances,” Wei Wuxian repeats with a nod. “And what if I refuse to go?”

 

This feels more about a principle, now, than it does about a conference. Lan Wangji remains quiet. Slashes of rain bear down on the windows and walls, thunder trembling through the floor.

 

After another moment of silence, Wei Wuxian speaks again. “You said I wasn’t a prisoner of the GusuLan.”

 

Lan Wangji’s reply is low-voiced, emphatic. “You are not.”

 

“Then why do I feel like one?” Wei Wuxian says, and Lan Wangji can only think of his father’s gaunt face, the last time he’d seen him alive. His mother’s house, gathering snow in thick and silent layers.

 

The sudden nausea he feels is gut-clenching. His father had loved his mother. It had not been enough. What mattered was that his mother had not loved him in return. What mattered was that his mother had died alone in confinement, ensnared by a love she never asked for.

 

Provided his own childhood, Lan Wangji has always been of the conviction that he could never repeat his father’s mistakes. Could never consciously bear or carry out his family’s curse.

 

And yet, here he is. Hopelessly, freshly, sickly in love with someone who resents him. Who feels like his captive.

 

Wei Wuxian is staring at him, waiting for him to say something. Perhaps to deny it, even. But Lan Wangji is struck dumb by a bone-deep aphasia. He cannot say anything at all, to that. Wei Wuxian had unwittingly landed a stunning strike, and Lan Wangji can only stare blankly back at him in reply.

 

At last, the silence stretches enough to feel taut, the appropriate moment for a reply long past. Wei Wuxian huffs, gives one nod as if confirming something to himself. Then he vanishes out into the rain, the sliding door slamming shut behind him.

 

Lan Wangji stares after him, his feet rooted in place. He could go after him, attempt to draw him out of the rain, but it’s clear Wei Wuxian wants to be left alone. 

 

He is not sure how much time passes, standing there and staring at a closed door, waiting for it to open again.

 

The evening deepens, the storm unrelenting, and Wei Wuxian does not return. It occurs to Lan Wangji, in slow-cresting waves, that he might not. So at last, Lan Wangji begins to move, to woodenly prepare for his nighttime rituals. He combs his hair, cleans and treats it with the oils in his qiankun pouch. He sets out his robes for the next day, then settles into his sleep-clothes. The same rituals he has followed every single night, without fail, since he was a child, since he was old enough to care for himself.

 

Finally, he sits on the bed, the candles brought low.

 

And Lan Wangji does as Lan Wangji is wont to do. He waits.

 

 

It’s after another shichen of lying in bed, staring at the dark ceiling, that Lan Wangji hears Wei Wuxian come in; hears the scrape of the door sliding quietly open, the swell of rainfall made loud, and then shut. Wei Wuxian’s footfalls are tentative as he approaches the bed, as though he’s trying not to wake Lan Wangji. As if it were a possibility Lan Wangji could sleep, with Wei Ying gone, out in the rain and dark. His heart still feels like a wire coiled tight, sharp and tense and stinging.

 

Wei Wuxian lies down next to him, curling in close. He’s damp from the rain. He smells like fresh, wet earth, woodfire smoke from stalls in town; a little like sweet rice wine. Lan Wangji keeps his eyes closed, though he’s certain the stiffness of his posture gives him away.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says quietly after another moment. “Are you awake? You are, aren’t you?”

 

Slowly, Lan Wangji’s eyes open, and he stares at the intricate carvings in the canopy above them. Wei Wuxian sighs, a hot sound next to Lan Wangji’s ear.

 

“I’m sorry,” Wei Wuxian whispers. “I shouldn’t have lashed out at you. You have no more control over this situation than I do. It’s not like you were given a choice, either. I’m not the only one who has the right to be frustrated.”

 

That’s where Wei Wuxian is wrong. Lan Wangji had a choice — to keep Wei Wuxian close to him, with the knowledge he may be unhappy, or to give him away to a stranger. He’d made the selfish one. He hadn’t realized quite how selfish it was at the time, but it had been a theft of Wei Wuxian’s autonomy no less. 

 

“You’re stuck like this as much as I am,” Wei Wuxian continues, his voice still hushed. 

 

A curl of bile burns Lan Wangji’s chest. He had thought, over the past few weeks...

 

But he’d been naïve — and greedy — to think this was something Wei Wuxian could want, when he’d never had a choice to refuse. How can he expect Wei Wuxian to feel anything for him except contempt, in such a context?

 

“I’m not mad at you. I wasn’t earlier, either. Not with you. Okay?” Wei Wuxian hesitates, perhaps attempting to interpret Lan Wangji’s silence, then says softly, “You’ve been good to me.”

 

Lan Wangji opens his mouth to reply to this, but Wei Wuxian sweeps on before he can be interrupted. “I could’ve been foisted off on anyone, someone who might’ve — hurt me, or mistreated me. I know that I’ve been lucky.”

 

Lucky, to be forced into a marriage of convenience with Lan Wangji when Wei Wuxian does not love him, cannot love him. As if decent treatment isn’t the very base of what he deserves. There’s a taste like ash in Lan Wangji’s mouth.

 

Wei Wuxian keeps going, tentative but earnest and unmistakably sincere. “I’m lucky Lan Zhan is my husband.”

 

“Wei Ying.” Lan Wangji closes his eyes again. Wei Wuxian tenses slightly by his side at the sound of his voice, but doesn’t move away from him. 

 

There are numerous things Lan Wangji could say in response to that. A rebuttal. An apology. A promise that one day, Wei Wuxian will be free to do as he wishes, not tethered by the ankle to a man and a marriage he does not want.

 

Instead, he says, “If you want to go out, please don’t do so like that.”

 

Wei Wuxian pauses, then says, sounding thrown, “What?”

 

“I...” Lan Wangji trails off, then tries again. “I will not keep you here, against your will. You are free to go wherever you wish, whenever and for however long. But if you go again, do not go at night. Alone, when the weather is poor.”

 

“I,” Wei Wuxian says, then swallows. “Oh. Okay. Yeah, okay. I won’t.”

 

Lan Wangji moves to push the sheets off of himself, and Wei Wuxian flails a little in his surprise. “Lan Zhan ah, I didn’t mean for you to get up — what are you —”

 

“Come,” Lan Wangji says, rubbing a knuckle tiredly against his eye. “I will have more hot water brought in.”

 

“You really don’t need to —” Wei Wuxian protests, sitting upright in the bed. “Not when I was the one to…ah, Lan Zhan, it’s the middle of the night and I know that you —”

 

“You have been out in the cold and rain for an entire shichen,” Lan Wangji points out, and wraps his silk robe tighter around himself. A damp chill creeps in between his bare toes, slithers beneath his layers. “You could fall ill.”

 

Wei Wuxian stares at him from the bed for another moment, inscrutable in the dark. He seems as though he might voice another protest. Then he says, surprisingly compliant, “Okay,” and slides out of bed. Wei Wuxian watches as Lan Wangji re-dresses himself and ducks out into the rain, and he waits silently with his arms wrapped around his chest upon Lan Wangji’s return, radiating guilt as two of the inn staff help to bring in hot water.

 

Once they’re gone, Lan Wangji removes his re-dampened layers, folding them neatly until just the last robe remains. Wei Wuxian is still watching him without a word as Lan Wangji lights two more candles near the privacy screen. Wei Wuxian approaches the bath slowly, his wet hair clinging to his neck like ropes of seaweed. Then he stops and stares at Lan Wangji for a long moment. The look seems strangely expectant.

 

“Can I…” Wei Wuxian says, then drops his gaze and fidgets with his belt, uncharacteristically reticent. “May I entreat my husband’s help in preparing to bathe?”

 

Lan Wangji blinks, his breath catching in his throat. Wei Wuxian’s gaze darts to him again, assessing his reaction, though Lan Wangji keeps his features blank. He nods to the inquiry and sets down the candle. Wei Wuxian turns, his back to Lan Wangji and his dripping hair slung over his shoulder.

 

Tentatively, Lan Wangji eases one sodden layer off of Wei Wuxian’s shoulders, then the next. Wei Wuxian is surprisingly quiet, none of his usual teasing chatter or flirtations to fill the silence between them. Perhaps being outside, for so long and in such weather, has exhausted him. Perhaps it’s this deep and liminal hour of night, in which speech seems stranger than silence. Lan Wangji’s fingers work to unpeel each robe until only the inner remains, clinging like wet paper to Wei Wuxian’s skin. This close, Lan Wangji can see the bumps grazing the back of Wei Wuxian’s neck, hairs raised with the cold. Wei Wuxian’s skin is warm regardless, soft against the tips of Lan Wangji’s fingers as he works the last layer off with his heart in his throat. He does not allow his eyes to linger too long, though he quickly drinks in the snatches of Wei Wuxian’s musculature, the lithe wings of his shoulders and his slim waist, raised whip welts branded into his skin from Zidian. He just barely keeps himself from touching, from drifting his fingers over the scars, long faded with age. Wei Wuxian holds himself very still, the line of his shoulders taut. There are only the wet inner trousers left now, clinging to the hidden curves of him.

Lan Wangji takes the cue for the dismissal, treading a respectful step back before he turns and drapes Wei Wuxian’s wet robes over the side of the privacy screen. Then he moves mechanically toward the bed to lie down again. He listens, for the next few minutes, to the sounds of Wei Wuxian bathing, the quiet slop of water against the wooden basin and the crackling noises of soap moving over Wei Wuxian’s skin, through his hair.

Wei Wuxian watches him from the privacy screen for a moment — assessing his reaction, maybe — and his expression is unreadable in the low light, but he makes no move to cover himself or any modest exclamations, and Lan Wangji, like a man possessed, can’t pull his eyes away from the sudden, startling reveal of so much new skin. The vee of Wei Wuxian’s hipbones is sharp, pronounced, tapering to a dark thatch of pubic hair and his cock hanging soft between his legs. Not as large here as Lan Wangji, but still decently sized and — nicely shaped, slightly flared at the head. Lan Wangji’s mouth waters with a sudden flood of spit, his vision blurring. Released from the spell, Lan Wangji turns his face back toward the ceiling, his skin overheated and his mouth dry. Shamefully, he can feel that he’s partially hard, an interested throb in his groin just from the sight of Wei Wuxian naked, as innocent as it had been. Wei Wuxian has never been a champion of modesty; reared with a younger brother and several other boys his age, he would have had a very different upbringing from Lan Wangji. Lan Wangji seeing him unclothed is no different from anyone else. But Lan Wangji cannot shake the strange sense that it had been intentional. That Wei Wuxian had been offering something to him, some unlocked threshold of intimacy.

 

Lan Wangji keeps his eyes shut tight when Wei Wuxian joins him in bed a moment later, warmth and a waft of floral soap. Wei Wuxian had been naked moments ago and now he’s in Lan Wangji’s bed, close enough that Lan Wangji can feel the push of Wei Wuxian’s breath against his skin. Under the sheets, Lan Wangji clenches his fist tight enough that his knuckles silently crack, his fingernails cutting into his palm. The sensation distracts him from everything else, grounds him. Wanting Wei Ying in this way, it’s — it’s unruly. It’s undisciplined. 

 

It’s futile.

 

The thoughts leave him sleepless enough that by the time morning comes, his eyes feel gritty and heavy. Whatever odd, silent tension had thickened between them last night has evaporated by the time morning sun breaks over the room. Wei Wuxian brightly rambles to him all during breakfast, so entirely himself that Lan Wangji has to take a long moment to question if any of the events of the previous night had happened at all. In any case, wishful hallucination or not, he can no longer look at Wei Wuxian without visualizing the shape of him under all of his layers. One particular shape, to be specific. Lan Wangji sips his tea with deep, meditative focus, nodding to all of Wei Wuxian’s questions and resolutely ignoring the heat in his ears that threatens to give him away. Though he is a married man, and none of his sect’s rules forbid fantasizing about one’s spouse, it doesn’t feel proper regardless, their situation being what it is.

“No?” Wei Wuxian says blankly.

 

“As Wei Ying said,” Lan Wangji returns, “there are those here who need our help.”

 

“But,” Wei Wuxian says. “The...the sect conference. You said yourself that you can’t miss it.”

 

“There will be more conferences,” Lan Wangji says firmly. “This demands our attention more. My sect will understand.”

 

Wei Wuxian hesitates, studying him for a long moment. “Lan Zhan, are you sure? Your sect doesn’t seem like the, um — understanding type. No offense.”

 

Lan Wangji purses his lips and replies, “Eat.”

 

Wei Wuxian does, but Lan Wangji doesn’t miss his small, hidden smile, or the way his gaze softens, just a little.

Tracking down the two yaoguai, with the skills shared between them, does not take long.

 

The town of Pailou is small, and a fearful word travels as quickly as wildfire catching. Lan Wangji and Wei Wuxian simply follow the clamor of it, with Wei Wuxian doing most of the actual questioning. Wei Wuxian has some contraption to help him, a compass he’d started creating (“a work in progress,” so he says) that can detect resentful energy.

 

The tracking is, surprisingly enough, the easy part. The fight itself shouldn’t be any more difficult, given their joint prowess as swordsmen. But they discover quickly, when they catch up to the creatures in the middle of the woods, that the yaoguai are jueyuan, monkey-like creatures that can attack from the trees with lethal agility. 

 

Lan Wangji guides Bichen easily, flashing strikes in the growing dark as the jueyuan screech at them from the trees and dodge the blows. None of his hits land. A jueyuan possesses a near-human intelligence, Lan Wangji knows, and they are in their element here, attacking from treetops. Eventually, he and Wei Wuxian have to chase them on foot, following the echo of the creatures’ screeches as they move from tree to tree.

 

It should be a simple hunt; Wei Wuxian had made it sound like it would be. Lan Wangji knows, later, that he can’t have predicted a cultivator as talented as Wei Wuxian would get hurt. But as the screeching increases in volume, he hears Wei Wuxian yell, “Lan Zhan, look out!” and it’s enough to distract him from what matters; enough for him to turn on instinct toward a dark, apish blur already scurrying away. By the time he hears Wei Wuxian cry out, it’s already too late.

 

When Lan Wangji whirls back around, the other jueyuan is retreating into the treetops with furious, squalling shrieks, and Wei Wuxian — Wei Ying is — crumpling against one of the nearest bamboo trees, his face ashen in the lengthening dark. The screeches grow quieter, more distant through the trees. The jueyuan are escaping, retreating. If Lan Wangji were a worthy cultivator, he would follow after them, stop at nothing until the job is done and other lives are spared.

 

The thought does not cross his mind. He races to Wei Wuxian’s side, dropping to his knees and steeling a hand on his shoulder.

 

“Wei Ying,” he says. His own voice sounds very far away.

 

“I’m fine,” Wei Wuxian rasps, and as he speaks, blood drips down his chin, down his neck. He curses and spits; more blood. So much blood that it doesn’t seem possible all of it could come from inside of him.

 

Lan Wangji has never felt fear like this. Night hunts and fights have never rattled him; since as long as he can remember, he has been schooled in disciplines of calm, meditative control in such situations. True fear like this is paralytic. He can hardly move his limbs, like he’s suspended in a frozen lake.

 

Wei Wuxian swears again, then explains through wet gasps, “Talisman — rebounded — curse.”

 

It’s clear, with each word, that he’s struggling to breathe. He grips at Lan Wangji’s arms tightly with the panic of a drowning man. His eyes are wide, afraid against what are clearly his best efforts, his lips glistening and dark.

 

“Tell me what to do,” Lan Wangji says helplessly. He is as familiar with curses as his studies have allowed, but he has nowhere near Wei Wuxian’s breadth of knowledge.

 

“Go,” Wei Wuxian rasps, gesturing in the direction of the vanished jueyuan.

 

Lan Wangji is abruptly furious at the suggestion. “No.”

 

“Lan —” Wei Wuxian tries, then coughs harder, curling in on himself. 

 

There is a yao curse Lan Wangji is familiar with, a rebound curse — one in which the injuries inflicted on the yao are transferred back to the caster. If that’s the case, it means Wei Wuxian had injured the creature in turn. Badly. Without a core to mediate the damage, it’s likely Wei Wuxian had killed it, or at least brought it near death. The curse would have struck Wei Wuxian squarely in return, dealing whatever state of injury had been inflicted on the creature.

 

Whatever the solution, it won’t be found out here, in the middle of the woods as the evening grows darker and darker. Lan Wangji bundles Wei Wuxian into his arms, who is either too weak or too incapacitated to protest, and guides them both back to town on his sword. Wei Wuxian is still trying to breathe around the blood with wet, rattling gasps. There is still so much of it, seemingly without a source. The front of Lan Wangji’s clean white robes is stained as dark as a wine-spill.

 

He lands them once they return to town, then ignores the innkeeper’s surprised shout when he blazes inside the inn, both of them blood-soaked and drawing stares. He carries Wei Wuxian up to their room and seals the door shut behind him with a quick spell. Then, quickly, he transfers Wei Wuxian onto the bed. 

 

Wei Wuxian is still hanging onto his sleeve with a bunched fist. His face is blanched, drawn with pain. His eyes are clenched shut, his breathing shallow and a sheen of sweat over his face. Blood keeps bubbling between his lips, running down his chin as he coughs around it. 

 

This feeling, too, is new. To experience Wei Ying’s pain as acutely as if it’s his own simply by seeing it, simply for the fact that it’s Wei Ying. To know that he would lay his own life down, if it meant one specific person wouldn’t be in pain a moment longer.

 

Lan Wangji begins to tear at Wei Wuxian’s layers, burrowing and unpeeling the various robes until Wei Wuxian’s torso is bare. Wei Wuxian is barely conscious; if he were, he’d likely make some teasing joke about Lan Wangji’s impropriety. Lan Wangji wants to be teased. Every day, for the rest of his life.

 

He finds the curse mark easily, a black blight on Wei Wuxian’s side.

 

Lan Wangji knows little about Wei Wuxian’s school of cultivation. He is not by any means an expert in curse work, not the way Wei Wuxian is in all matters relating to this. But he knows enough. Enough for this.

 

He places two fingers to the black wound on Wei Wuxian’s side, and he begins.

“Fine,” Lan Wangji replies. “And you?”

“Okay,” he replies.

Given Wei Wuxian’s dramatic build-up of suspense, Lan Wangji is half-expecting to be snatched off his feet the moment they enter the brothel.

 

The reality is much duller, to his relief. They are thoroughly ignored upon entry, only drawing a few openly confused looks from surrounding patrons. Lan Wangji keeps his gaze fixed forward, narrowing his line of vision to block them out. He can feel his jaw is clenched with tension. Even being here is a violation.

 

“...huh,” Wei Wuxian says as he looks around, sounding oddly deflated. “It isn’t like I thought it would be.”

 

A red-lipped young woman, dressed in a flowing, arctic-blue hanfu, approaches them with a curt greeting. Her dark hair is pinned back in a bun and adorned with a jade floral hairpin. “What services are you seeking, gongzimen?”

 

“None!” Wei Wuxian interrupts, sliding in front of Lan Wangji like he’s physically shielding him. “We’re only here to ask for information.”

Her tone had only shifted when it had become clear Wei Wuxian would not be making an immediate transaction. Her engagement with Wei Wuxian is nothing beyond selling a service. She is not interested in Wei Wuxian, only his money. Lan Wangji knows all of this, rationally. Knowing it does nothing to stop his fists from tightening at his sides, a streak of possessiveness rearing its ugly, snapping head.

The woman slinks forward and draws one finger down the line of Wei Wuxian’s throat, who audibly swallows. She sticks her lower lip out in a pout, looking at him through her long black lashes. “Are you sure there’s...nothing I can do to change your mind?”

The woman blinks at his tone and redirects her attention to him. She does not flinch, to her credit, but her eyes widen slightly at whatever expression she sees on Lan Wangji’s face.

The woman narrows her eyes at Lan Wangji with clear skepticism, cutting her eyes up then down. “Like hell are you married to him. A scrawny rascal like you with a specimen like that.”

 

Wei Wuxian splutters in his indignation. “I’ll have you know that I was ranked the fourth-most handsome in the —”
