Only silence answers him for a moment. Lan Qiren has a hawk’s gaze focused on Lan Wangji’s hand still resting on Wei Wuxian’s shoulder, his mouth puckered as though he’s tasted something sour, but he says nothing to reproach him outright. 

 

“Prioritize one’s sect,” Lan Qingsheng says at last, in icy tones.

 

“Put the needs of one’s spouse above all others,” Lan Wangji recites, his hand tightening on Wei Wuxian’s shoulder.

 

His words cast a pall over the other two elders, their faces drawing and tightening.

 

“Be diligent in one’s sect responsibilities,” Lan Boqin says, his teeth clenched.

 

“Protect the weak and vulnerable,” Lan Wangji answers. 

 

There are none in the Cloud Recesses who know the precepts as readily as Lan Wangji does. Not even his seniors. He can sense his shufu watching him, a little grimly, but with a detectable glint of something else. He would not go so far as to call it pride, but. Maybe.

 

“Do not associate with evil,” Lan Qingsheng snaps, a vein in his forehead pulsing. He is, of course, referring to Wei Ying’s alternative cultivation work. Ever so slightly, Wei Wuxian’s shoulder tenses under Lan Wangji’s palm.

 

Lan Wangji’s voice, when it comes again, is much quieter. “Love all beings.”

 

It was the precept he had struggled with the most as a child. He had not understood, for a very long time, how could one truly love everyone they encountered. Especially one such as him, who tolerated so few. It didn’t seem realistic or fair, nor was it as practically defined as the other disciplines.

 

But he has changed, after all. Loving Wei Ying has allowed him, slowly but surely, to find love in all things.

 

“Qingsheng-qianbei, Boqin-qianbei,” Lan Xichen interrupts, perhaps because both elders look as though they’re about to spit. “Wangji and Wei-gongzi have had a long journey and are no doubt exhausted. If you wish to discuss this with them further, it can be done at a later time, surely.”

 

The elders grumble but concede, their lines of argument spent. Lan Wangji glances at his xiongzhang. He keeps his expression neutral, but he knows Lan Xichen will interpret the thank you for what it is. Lan Xichen’s eyes meet his, and his mouth quirks at the corner.

 

“I’m glad you’ve returned safely, Wangji,” Lan Xichen says, then transfers a pleasant look to Wei Wuxian. “And Wei-gongzi. It is rare to see Wangji in such high spirits.”

 

At this, Lan Qiren turns to leave, following after the other two elders where they’ve begun to disperse. Then he pauses in his steps, and turns halfway back to Lan Wangji.

 

“I trust I will see Wangji for supper this evening,” he says. His throat works for a moment, his beard bobbing, before he adds, grudgingly, “And Wei-gongzi.”

 

Tension uncoils in Lan Wangji’s chest, a tightness he hadn’t realized was so closely wound. He nods, a new lightness rising in him.

 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says. “Yes, shufu.”

 

Lan Qiren gives a quiet hmph and moves away again, following after where Lan Qingsheng and Lan Boqin are already several paces ahead.

 

“See you tonight, Lan-xiansheng!” Wei Wuxian shouts with a vigorous wave to Lan Qiren’s back, who makes no indication he’s heard Wei Wuxian. Wei Wuxian winces and says, quieter to Lan Wangji, “Too much, huh?”

 

With only his brother as a witness, Lan Wangji feels comfortable taking Wei Wuxian’s wrist, guiding them past Lan Xichen into the Cloud Recesses and heading toward the direction of the jingshi. 

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says several minutes later, once they near the front of the library. He tugs on Lan Wangji’s hand to direct him, pulling him through the open door. They are alone here for now, the depths of the library as silent and austere as they always are. Its scent has always been soothing to Lan Wangji, ink and parchment and the lingering remnants of incense, an echo of the entire days he’d passed here as a child researching or reading. In more recent years, the smell has reminded him of Wei Ying and the summertime, after so many of those afternoons spent here together.

 

Like a dream from a younger self, the present Wei Wuxian backs up against one of the walls, pulling Lan Wangji closer to him as he goes and slatting their fingers together.

 

“You really didn’t have to do that,” Wei Wuxian begins. “I know that I only make your life here more difficult, and I know that I...I’m not really…”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji interrupts, a low murmur. His thumb catches on the soft curve of Wei Wuxian’s cheek, a slow stroke. Wei Wuxian’s eyes flutter half-shut, his throat hitching around a swallow.

 

“I already made the Jiangs’ lives hard enough in Lotus Pier,” he says, with a wry curve of his mouth. “You don’t need to go to war on my behalf with your elders. My ego can handle their aspersions, trust me.”

 

“Hm,” Lan Wangji says. “That may be so. But I will not tolerate it.”

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian starts again.

 

“There are three I hold most dear,” Lan Wangji interrupts, swift in his conviction. “My sect. My family. You. No two are incompatible with the other. This, I know very well to be true. It’s of no consequence what others may believe.”

 

Wei Wuxian stares at him for a long time, his mouth parted. Then he leans in, pushing up slightly onto his toes, to kiss Lan Wangji, careful and deep. Wei Wuxian’s kisses are usually fleeting, impatient bites, messy and sloppy and eager. But this is different, heated and slow. 

 

Wei Wuxian fits a palm to Lan Wangji’s cheek when he pulls away. His eyes are soft, wondering. “You really…love me, don’t you.”

 

“Yes.” So much. Lan Wangji’s heart is still racing from kissing him. “Wei Ying.”

 

“Can you,” Wei Wuxian says, then licks his lips. “Lan Zhan, can you show me?”

 

It is an exercise in willpower not to do so right there on the library floor, as he’s imagined so many times before, but Lan Wangji does possess some decency still, so he only takes Wei Wuxian’s hand and pulls him, very quickly and too roughly, in the direction of the jingshi. Wei Wuxian laughs a little breathlessly in his wake, nearly jogging to keep up, but he doesn’t let go of Lan Wangji’s hand.

 

The moment they’re through the jingshi’s door, after it slides shut behind them, Lan Wangji crowds Wei Wuxian against the nearest flat surface, kissing and biting whatever skin he can reach. He already has one hand squeezing along Wei Wuxian’s waist, the other tangled in his hair. Wei Wuxian gives another winded laugh, then gives over to half-panted ahs and whimpers, squirming under Lan Wangji’s touches.

 

“You know,” he says a moment later, when he’s apparently recovered his ability to speak. “We never — ah, fuck, ah — broke in our marital bed together.”

 

“Hm,” Lan Wangji says, making quick work of Wei Wuxian’s belt. “Negligent.”

 

“What should we do about that?” Wei Wuxian wonders as he takes Lan Wangji’s outer robe in his hands, peeling it off of his shoulders with a push. Lan Wangji can’t answer because Wei Wuxian is kissing him again, both hands steeled to either side of his face so he can’t pull away. Lan Wangji drags him by the front of his robes, walking them both back until they find the bed, until Wei Wuxian is tumbling down on top of him with an airless, high-pitched laugh.

 

Lan Wangji flips them both with ease, Wei Wuxian’s back crashing into the mattress as he pants up at Lan Wangji, his eyes and his breath dazed. Lan Wangji’s hand moves to the back of Wei Wuxian’s head, and his fingers work to untie the red ribbon, so the knot of his ponytail won’t dig into his skull while he’s pressed against the bed. Wei Wuxian is still half-dressed, but with the belt missing, his front layers are split open, a deep plunge of bare skin to his navel.

 

“Ah, Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian says. His voice is low but gentle. “The way you look at me.”

 

Lan Wangji rewards this by sucking a love-bite into Wei Wuxian’s neck, hard enough that blood rises to the skin and Wei Wuxian’s fingers scrabble ineffectively at his shoulders.

 

“Lan Zhan!” Wei Wuxian protests. “We have dinner with your family later, I can’t show up looking ravaged — ”

 

“On your back or on your front?” Lan Wangji asks, sliding a hand inside Wei Wuxian’s trousers to cup his erection, which rapidly hardens from half-mast to full in his grip.

 

“I cannot believe I’m being treated like this,” Wei Wuxian whines, making a dramatic show of trying to get away from Lan Wangji’s probing hand. “On my back. Lan Zhan, I didn’t realize I’d married such a brute, my husband is an insatiable beast who takes what he wants from his poor, helpless —”

 

“Be quiet,” Lan Wangji says; not out of a true desire for Wei Wuxian to stop talking, which he is helplessly fond of, so much as to watch Wei Wuxian’s jaw snap shut at the roughness of the command, his cheeks reddening and his eyes going bright. “Show me how much you want it.”

 

Wei Wuxian does. It is good sex. Possibly their best yet, if only because each time is impossibly better than the last, the more they know each other’s bodies, what riles the other up or pushes to an edge. Afterward, they lie together silent and winded and panting up at the ceiling in shared disbelief as sweat cools on their skin. Wei Wuxian is complaining softly about soreness, which Lan Wangji knows by now to be performance because if Wei Ying were truly in pain, he would be the last to voice it. Lan Wangji slings an arm over Wei Wuxian, pulling him in closer to rest as the afternoon sun slowly bakes from white to gold through the windows, leaving brassy prints on their skin.

 

“Are you happy in the jingshi?” Lan Wangji finally asks, once the bone-deep exhaustion has lifted and resettled into simple contentment. 

 

Wei Wuxian shifts next to him, squirming from half-awake to fully alert. “It’s different from what I’m used to. It’s...quiet. Very clean. Mmm, orderly. But Lan Zhan, I’ll like anywhere that you are. Anywhere that I can keep pestering you.”

 

Silence is indeed in the name. Lan Wangji had never considered anything but a quiet, solitary lifestyle for himself, before Wei Ying. He has realized, over the last couple of months, that the two may not be compatible, and it is obvious which his priority is.

 

“Would you want to live somewhere else?” Lan Wangji murmurs, tracing a bud of sunlight on Wei Wuxian’s shoulder with his knuckle.

 

Wei Wuxian starts to fidget, clearly gearing up to deflect. “Lan Zhan, I know how important your sect is to you. Living here was a compromise I agreed to when I married you. I wouldn’t want you to go anywhere that makes you unhappy.”

 

“Wei Ying’s unhappiness is far more important to me,” Lan Wangji says.

 

“Don’t worry about me,” Wei Wuxian protests, as if such an instruction were even possible. “I’m really fine, Lan Zhan! I’m low-maintenance. You could really put me up anywhere and I’d be okay. As long as there’s a roof over my head, my basic needs are met.”

 

Lan Wangji is silent for another moment, waiting patiently for Wei Wuxian to relax again. He had gone slightly tense at the line of conversation, almost like he’d been charging up to argue.

 

“What if I built a home for us somewhere in the mountains?” Lan Wangji says. “Still within the Cloud Recesses, but far enough away for privacy. For just the two of us.”

 

Wei Wuxian hesitates, then says tentatively, “Yeah? You think?”

 

“Mn,” Lan Wangji says. “What would you like to see there?”

 

Wei Wuxian thinks on the request for a moment, battering his lower lip with his teeth. His lashes are not as black as Lan Wangji had once thought — they’re almost tawny in the afternoon sun. He’s so beautiful that Lan Wangji feels his heart give a faint stutter, a shudder of disbelief. It doesn’t seem possible, to have him like this. It sometimes feels as though he’s still waking from a dream.

 

“Sorry,” Wei Wuxian says after another moment lost in thought, then blinks at Lan Wangji sheepishly. “I’ve never even thought it was a possibility to have a home of my own, so I’m a little short on imagination.”

 

“Take your time,” Lan Wangji says softly, pressing a kiss to his neck.

 

“What about…” Wei Wuxian says after another moment. “I know they’re a lot of work, so definitely say no if you don’t want to, but what about a lotus pond? Ahhh, it feels ridiculous to even ask, in a climate like this, but —”

 

“Yes,” Lan Wangji says. “What else?”

 

“Oh,” Wei Wuxian says, then narrows his eyes in thought again. “Hang on, that was the only idea I had. Oh, what about the rabbits? I know you still keep them around, Lan Zhan ah, I’m in on the big secret now that you’re much too soft to have gotten rid of them.”

 

“Hm,” Lan Wangji says, an amused affirmative. “I care for them on the back mountain. We can take the rabbits.”

 

Wei Wuxian flashes a smile with a surprised, uncomplicated kind of joy. “Yeah?”

 

“Yes,” Lan Wangji says. “What else?”

 

“Aiyoo, my husband is making me do so much work,” Wei Wuxian complains, “after what he just did to me.”

 

“What about a garden?” Lan Wangji asks, and Wei Wuxian lights up further.

 

“Yes, definitely,” Wei Wuxian says, “that way I can grow things and cook for you!” 

 

Lan Wangji is vaguely familiar with the horrors of Wei Wuxian’s cooking, but the thought is sweet, and Lan Wangji would eat anything Wei Wuxian made with his own hands. 

 

Wei Wuxian continues, “I would prefer if there was….mm, I don’t know, a field that I could work in during the days. I know that’s impossible, living in the mountains.”

 

“You can keep going to the villages to help,” Lan Wangji suggests, remembering Wei Wuxian’s worn-in happiness that evening early in their marriage. “I will go with you.”

 

Wei Wuxian brightens again, the corners of his mouth curving up. “Really?”

 

Lan Wangji nods.

 

Wei Wuxian wriggles closer to Lan Wangji so that all of their bare skin can press against each other. “I’d really like that.” He peers up at Lan Wangji doubtfully. “Lan Zhan, are you really going to build us a house?”

 

“Yes,” Lan Wangji answers promptly. He does not say what he does not mean. “As soon as I can have it finished, we can move there.”

 

Wei Wuxian smiles again, then presses his forehead against Lan Wangji’s chest. “I like you so much.” Before Lan Wangji can recover properly enough to answer, Wei Wuxian continues, “When I was younger, I always thought I’d probably love whoever I married — if I got the choice as to who I was marrying, that is. But I never thought about liking them this much. I didn’t know I could like anyone this much.”

 

“Wei Ying,” Lan Wangji says softly. He can’t articulate, suddenly, the correct words to voice how much he feels the same; that he’d never imagined liking or loving anyone at all, before Wei Ying. Marriage had always been something cold and secular to him, purely obligatory. The best possible scenario he had envisioned for himself had been a partnership that was peaceful only for the fact that it was unchallenging, ideally one that permitted him his space. It hadn’t been until he met Wei Ying that he had realized how quickly he could revoke solitude. It hadn’t been until Wei Ying that he’d understood love stories; that he, all at once, had understood everything.

 

“Lan Zhan,” Wei Wuxian speaks up, his voice still muffled against Lan Wangji’s skin. “Thank you.”

 

Lan Wangji frowns. “For?”

 

“Back at the library just now, I asked you to show me how you love me,” Wei Wuxian says, and looks up at Lan Wangji. Lan Wangji has never seen him quite like this; so strangely unguarded and free of teasing, the color in his eyes a liquid warmth. “And you did. You’ve loved me better than anyone else ever has, or — or ever could, I think. So: Thank you.”

 

Before Lan Wangji can stop himself, he’s speaking. “I want to marry you again.”

 

Wei Wuxian blinks, his eyes widening in surprise. “What?”

 

“I would marry you again every day, if I could,” Lan Wangji says, nearly tripping the words out in his haste. “But I would like...a second wedding. A private one, in which we are both willing.”

 

A love wedding, he does not say.

 

Wei Wuxian is nodding vigorously even before Lan Wangji has finished speaking, his eyes still round. “Yes, I — Lan Zhan, yes. Of course. Please. Marry me again, or marry me a hundred times, I don’t care — just — yes.”

 

“Okay,” Lan Wangji says, and he does not smile, but it’s a near thing. This, finally, feels like the beginning. “Where would you like to start?”
